label: fig:cdcx_arbitrary
descriptions: Arbitrary-length logical constant-depth CNOT ladder. A ‚äï on a measured data bit is flipped if the sum (modulo 2) of the measured ancilla bits above it with an ‚äï is 1. The qubits with/without a Hadamard applied at the start are ancilla/data qubits, respectively.

label: fig:cdcx_unencoded
descriptions: Logical circuit for a 5 CNOT, constant-depth CNOT-ladder on a 4√ó2 grid of qubits. The brackets surround qubits on the same row. The dashed lines separate the circuit into three parts: the first creates a Bell pair between the ancilla row and the second data row, the second consists of the CNOTs from the first two sections of the original circuit (Figure <ref>) being executed in parallel, and the third consists of the final CNOT from the original circuit, measurement, and classical correction.

label: fig:decompos
descriptions: Example of how redundant CX pairs appear and how to remove them. (a) will decompose a multi-qubit controlled operator into RCCX gates (illustrated as CCX gates in the figure) and a single controlled-U gate. (b) can eliminate redundant control operations depending on the states of qubits. (c) Redundant CX pairs can be removed once they are identified as redundant.

descriptions: Quantum circuit and Venn diagrams for the conjunction (, and) and the disjunction (, or) operation in (a) and (b), respectively. A and B are boolean variables being either 0 or 1 for and .

label: fig:conjunction
descriptions: Quantum circuit and Venn diagrams for the conjunction (, and) and the disjunction (, or) operation in (a) and (b), respectively. A and B are boolean variables being either 0 or 1 for and .

label: Fig: BS by ZBS
descriptions: Implementation of a beamsplitter operation using the ZBS gate. When the internal qubit is prepared in a computational basis state, the ZBS gate implements a beamsplitter operation in a phononic network. In this case, the internal qubit is initialized in the ground state ‚Üì.

label: Fig: CBS with BS and ZBS
descriptions: CBS gate implementation using a ZBS gate and a beamsplitter operator, based on the relation between œÉÃÇ z and 1 1.

label: Fig: QND with ZBS
descriptions: QND measurements for total number parity with the ZBS gate. When the modes are in the Fock states, the internal qubit encodes the total number parity of the two modes without changing their states.

label: fig:dirichlet lcu circuit
descriptions: Quantum circuit for LCU of second derivative operator with boundary conditions on a simply or non-simply connected domain in d-dimensions using low-order stencil ‚Ñí^(BC). The subnormalization 4 d results from Œª = 4 for the 3 point stencil, which we then combine d times. Here we use the notation prep as the unitary which prepares the finite difference coefficients on the stencil register and D d as the unitary which prepares the equal superposition over d states on the dim register where S^j l refers to the modular increment-by-j operator in direction l. We use the ‚äò convention to mean controlled over every state. Appending an additional register of log(Œ∑) qubits and selecting over shift operators both in dimension and particle indices will implement the Œ∑-particle Laplacian over d-dimensions.

label: fig:enter-label
descriptions: Quantum circuit to implement (2(Œª + Œ≤), m+l)-block encoding of a finite difference approximation to the differential operator with arbitrary boundary conditions. dom is an oracle which marks each point |x‚ü© in the [N^d] with a two-bit label |x‚ü©|b 0,b 1‚ü©, with '0 0' indicating interior points, '0 1' indicating boundary points and '1 0' indicating exterior points. Here, U L is a block encoding of the differential operator defined with periodic boundary conditions on [0,L]^d in matrix form and U B is a block encoding of the Dirichlet, Neumann, or Robin boundary condition in matrix form. U f implements the unitary transformation |b 0,b 1‚ü©‚Üí (-1)^b 0‚äï b 1|b 0,b 1‚ü© and U f' implements |b 0,b 1‚ü©‚Üí (-1)^b 0‚äï 1 ‚äï b 1|b 0,b 1‚ü©, to cause the summed operators to be projected onto the appropriate boundary modes. Because dom is not restricted to marking points that correspond to a domain with orthogonal boundary faces, this procedure can be used to implement a broad family of boundary conditions.

label: fig:basecircuitForwardEvolution
descriptions: A depiction of ‚Ñ¨(‚Ñã , t, œµ, 0), that is equivalent to e^-i ‚Ñã t.

label: fig:basecircuitInversionSubcircuit
descriptions: A depiction of a subcircuit, ‚Ñ¨(‚Ñã, t, œµ, 1), that is approximately equal to e^i ‚Ñã t/(L - 1), where each ‚Ñ¨^(k) j is an independent ‚Äì from all other ‚Ñ¨^(k) j ‚Äì uniformly chosen element of the relevant ùîæ ‚Ñã'.

label: fig:TrapAndTestDepiction
descriptions: A target (top) and trap (bottom) simulation corresponding to a simulation according to Hamiltonian, ‚Ñã, for a time duration t applied to an initial state, |œà 0‚ü©= ‚äó j = 1^N ( ùíú^' j ) |0‚ü©^‚äó N, before the measurements ‚Ñ≥= ‚äó j = 1^N ( ùíü^' j ) ùíµ^‚äó N are applied. H denotes a Hadamard gate, h ‚àà{0,1} is a uniformly random bit, ùíµ^' denotes applying a Pauli Z gate with probability 0.5 (each instance in the circuit is independent), and ùí´ j is a single-qubit Pauli gate, chosen uniformly at random independently for each j.

label: fig:TrapAndTestDepiction
descriptions: A target (top) and trap (bottom) simulation corresponding to a simulation according to Hamiltonian, ‚Ñã, for a time duration t applied to an initial state, |œà 0‚ü©= ‚äó j = 1^N ( ùíú^' j ) |0‚ü©^‚äó N, before the measurements ‚Ñ≥= ‚äó j = 1^N ( ùíü^' j ) ùíµ^‚äó N are applied. H denotes a Hadamard gate, h ‚àà{0,1} is a uniformly random bit, ùíµ^' denotes applying a Pauli Z gate with probability 0.5 (each instance in the circuit is independent), and ùí´ j is a single-qubit Pauli gate, chosen uniformly at random independently for each j.

label: fig:paritymeas

label: fig:XX_stabilizer
descriptions: The XX-stabilizer measurement between a pair of successive rows, shown for the 3√ó 3 Bacon-Shor code. The top panel shows the circuit involving the 2√ó 5=1 0 extended data qubits that make up two successive rows of a 3√ó 3 Bacon-Shor code, with one ancillary qubit and one flag qubit (bottom qubits). The bottom panel shows the order in which the extended data qubits are coupled via the CNOTs to the ancillary qubit to assure fault-tolerance properties (see Sec. <ref>). The blue circles are the data qubits; the yellow ones are the coupling ancillas; the arrows indicate the order in which the ancillary qubit is coupled to the extended data qubits in the two rows.

label: fig:logicalXmeas
descriptions: Logical X measurement on a single row. The logical outcome is given by the outcomes of the two X measurements. The row is valid only if both the X measurements give the same outcome and every Z measurement gives +1.

label: fig:HST
descriptions: Single-logical-qubit gadget implementing the gate G=H, S, or T. |Œ®‚ü© is the incoming state on which G is to be applied. For G=H, |Œ¶‚ü©=|+‚ü© L, g 1 is the identity, and g 2=X; for G=S, |Œ¶‚ü©=|Œ¶ S‚ü©, g 1=H, and g 2=Y=XZ; for G=T, |Œ¶‚ü©=|Œ¶ T‚ü©, g 1=H, and g 2=SX. The gate g 2 is applied, conditioned on the outcome of the X measurement. We note that the X and Z contained in the g 2 s do not need to be applied physically; see the main text.

label: fig:sketch_coherent_dissipative
descriptions: Schematic representation of (a) coherent state preparation via unitary evolution and post-selection, (b) dissipative state preparation via measurement and trace-over of ancillary degrees of freedom, and (c) conceptually equivalent implementation of dissipative state preparation by introducing more ancilla registers and deferring all measurements to the end. The initial state is œÅ 0, and the target state is œÉ. Both œÅ 0 and œÉ can be pure or mixed states.

label: fig:sketch_coherent_dissipative
descriptions: Schematic representation of (a) coherent state preparation via unitary evolution and post-selection, (b) dissipative state preparation via measurement and trace-over of ancillary degrees of freedom, and (c) conceptually equivalent implementation of dissipative state preparation by introducing more ancilla registers and deferring all measurements to the end. The initial state is œÅ 0, and the target state is œÉ. Both œÅ 0 and œÉ can be pure or mixed states.

label: QFT
descriptions: Quantum circuit designed to carry out the Fourier Transform in the unary basis. Single-qubit operations are phase gates, while vertical connections represent RBS gates with a rotation angle of œÄ/4. This arrangement mirrors the classical FFT butterfly structure by replacing each radix-2 operation with a phase gate followed by an RBS gate. The amplitudes in the input state vector |x‚ü©=‚àë i=0^7 x i|e i‚ü© properly permuted and encoded in the unary basis, are transformed into the desired output state.

label: fig:circ_qhmm
descriptions: Three time step generic Ansatz circuit QHMM. The latent register ‚ÄúL‚Äù contains n 1 = log 2(n^q L) qubits. The observed register ‚ÄúO‚Äù contains n 2 = log 2(n O) qubits. The ‚ÄúIS‚Äù gate can be any gate chosen to prepare the initial gate of the latent system. The ‚ÄúAC‚Äù gate is the chosen Ansatz circuit. The observed register is reset to the |0‚ü© state after each measurement.

label: fig:esu2
descriptions: Example circuit of QMM using an EfficientSU 2 Ansatz circuit for one time step. We use Ry and Rz rotation gates with one repetition. In our training process, we use 3 repetitions which results in a single Ansatz circuit depth of 2 1 gates.

Errors of the kind P ‚äó Z lead only to P error on respective data qubit as Z error on ancilla qubit does not propagate to data qubits. Each color denotes the gate that gets faulty and the corresponding error on data qubits.

label: fig:bare_normal_detector
descriptions: Propagation of error on data qubits when two qubit gates are followed by a P ‚äó X error, where P ‚àà{X,Y,Z}. label: fig:uid
descriptions: Circuit identity for ‚àë v=0^M-1 |v‚ü©‚ü®v| ‚äóTÃÇ^v showing how a linear combination of sequentially increasing powers of unitary TÃÇ <cit.> can be efficiently factorized.

label: fig:uid
descriptions: Circuit identity for ‚àë v=0^M-1 |v‚ü©‚ü®v| ‚äóTÃÇ^v showing how a linear combination of sequentially increasing powers of unitary TÃÇ <cit.> can be efficiently factorized.

label: fig:stm_proj_circ
descriptions: Symmetry group transform quantum circuit for the cyclic group ‚Ñ§ 8.

label: fig:s2_proj_circ
descriptions: S 2 symmetry projection circuit, acting on two system registers |Œ®‚ü© 0 and |Œ®‚ü© 1 of m qubits each and one ancilla qubit |Œì‚ü© 0. Comparing with Fig. <ref>, the QCT is reduced to a Hadamard gate, and the operation is implemented by an identity (no operation) and a controlled SWAP in the above. In this case, T GSA of the group S 2 reduces to the familiar SWAP test on the two system registers. This circuit can be used to project an arbitrary initial state on two system registers to their symmetric and anti-symmetric sectors.

label: Fig2:tgsa+qpe
descriptions: Circuit for symmetry-adapted quantum phase estimation, where the first two registers carry information of the irreps and the quantum state œà of our many-body system, while the last register with n qubits is the ancilla used for QPE. The input state œà is first decomposed into a coherent superposition of all irreps by TÃÇ GSA, and then a QPE or any other quantum subroutine can be applied to transform all irrep sectors of the quantum state simultaneously. The eigen energies and the irreps of quantum states will be stored in the first and the last register, where measurement (or amplitude amplification, not shown) can be performed to estimate the energies of states within a desired irrep.

label: fig:stm_proj_circAppendix
descriptions: Symmetry group transform for the cyclic group ‚Ñ§ 8, using an explicit projection circuit. Since the input state on the ancilla is the trivial irrep |0‚ü© 0 |0‚ü© 1 |0‚ü© 2, the QFT in Fig. <ref> can be simply replaced by a Hadamard transform in the above.

label: fig:ancilla_prep
descriptions: Circuit that sends all ancillas (A 1, A 2, and A 3 beginning in the state |0‚ü©) to the state |1‚ü© if the physical qubits (P 1 and P 2) are in the state |0‚ü©, and leaves them alone otherwise. The upper diagram shows the connectivity of the qubits on the hardware and the lower shows the circuit applied to these qubits.

label: fig:classification_flow
descriptions: Classification flow. System+ancillas processed by U(Œò); IC measurement outcomes feed a classical head that outputs the learned witness.

descriptions: Swap test circuit.

label: Compact Swap test circuit.
descriptions: Compact Swap test circuit.

label: fig:circuit-hp
descriptions: Circuit for U(H P, Œ≥ k) where H P=-2 Z 1 - 5/2 Z 2 - 9/2 Z 1 ‚äó Z 2 ‚äó Z 3.

label: fig:circuit-hm
descriptions: Circuit for U(H M, Œ≤ k) for the ansatz required to optimize the problem in Examples <ref> and <ref>.

label: circ
descriptions: Schematic of the entanglement swapping protocol. The segment before the red dashed line represents the initial preparation of two entangled qubit pairs. The segment after the line illustrates the entanglement swap operation, performed by measuring one qubit from each pair in an entangled basis‚Äìspecifically, the Bell basis in this case.

label: S
descriptions: Schematic of the entanglement swapping protocol between two partially entangled |Œ∑ m‚ü©,|Œ∑ p‚ü© states, outputting an entangled state which is either |Œ∑ m+p‚ü© or |Œ∑ m-p‚ü©. This setup of gates is what we will from now on refer to as the S operator, that acts upon four qubits and outputs two qubits. Whether the output is |Œ∑ m+p‚ü© or |Œ∑ m-p‚ü© can be determined by the measurements of second and third qubits. As we are not interested in what is the final state of a specific entanglement swap iteration, but rather in the possible states generated by it and its probabilities, we will not use that information.

label: multipartido
descriptions: Schematic of the entanglement swapping protocol between two partially entangled states |Œæ m‚ü©,|Œ∑ p‚ü©, outputting an entangled state which is either |Œæ m+p‚ü© or |Œæ m-p‚ü©. It is clear that only one qubit from |Œæ m‚ü© participates in the protocol.

label: star
descriptions: Schematic of a entanglement swapping protocol intended to create a GHZ state.

label: fig:bubble
descriptions: Bubble sort implemented by classical comparators.

label: fig:qcomp
descriptions: A quantum comparator consists of a comparison operator and a controlled-SWAP gate. An ancilla qubit is used to store the result of comparison and ensure the reversibility of the operation.

label: fig:qcomp

label: fig:qaoa
descriptions: QAOA circuit with variational parameters Œ≥, Œ≤ and Hamiltonians H C and H M. The blue section highlights a single QAOA layer which is repeated p times with individual parameters. A final measurement of ‚ü® H C‚ü© is used to classically optimize Œ≥ and Œ≤. After several iterations of that procedure, the circuit prepares the desired ground state of H C.

descriptions: Flag gadget equivalent to Fig. <ref>, due to the relation (<ref>). In case the error channel is also a Pauli channel ŒõÃÉ (<ref>), the dashed region acts as an effective Pauli channel ŒõÃÉ ¬±(œÅ U;Œª‚Éó) (<ref>), where the dependence on the measurement outcome m X=¬± 1 is emphasized.

label: fig:gadgets_repeated
